defs.docs:
A library of [`Futures`]-aware locking primitives.  These locks can safely
  be used in asynchronous environments like [`Tokio`].  When they block,
  they'll only block a single task, not the entire reactor.

attributes.value: /  A library of [`Futures`]-aware locking primitives.  These locks can safely
/  be used in asynchronous environments like [`Tokio`].  When they block,
/  they'll only block a single task, not the entire reactor.
/  These primitives generally work much like their counterparts from the
/  standard library.  But instead of blocking, they return a `Future` that
/  completes when the lock has been acquired.

defs.name: MutexGuard
defs.docs:
An RAII mutex guard, much like `std::sync::MutexGuard`.  The wrapped data
 can be accessed via its `Deref` and `DerefMut` implementations.

attributes.value: / An RAII mutex guard, much like `std::sync::MutexGuard`.  The wrapped data
/ can be accessed via its `Deref` and `DerefMut` implementations.

defs.name: MutexFut
defs.docs: A `Future` representing a pending `Mutex` acquisition.

defs.name: MutexWeak
defs.docs:
`MutexWeak` is a non-owning reference to a [`Mutex`].  `MutexWeak` is to
 [`Mutex`] as [`std::sync::Weak`] is to [`std::sync::Arc`].

defs.name: upgrade
defs.docs:
Tries to upgrade the `MutexWeak` to `Mutex`. If the `Mutex` was dropped
 then the function return `None`.

attributes.value: / Tries to upgrade the `MutexWeak` to `Mutex`. If the `Mutex` was dropped

defs.name: Mutex
defs.docs: A Futures-aware Mutex.

attributes.value: / `std::sync::Mutex` cannot be used in an asynchronous environment like Tokio,
/ because a mutex acquisition can block an entire reactor.  This class can be
/ used instead.  It functions much like `std::sync::Mutex`.  Unlike that
/ class, it also has a builtin `Arc`, making it accessible from multiple
/ threads.  It's also safe to `clone`.  Also unlike `std::sync::Mutex`, this
/ class does not detect lock poisoning.

defs.name: new
defs.docs: Create a new `Mutex` in the unlocked state.

attributes.value: / Create a new `Mutex` in the unlocked state.

defs.name: try_unwrap
defs.docs:
Consumes the `Mutex` and returns the wrapped data.  If the `Mutex` still
 has multiple references (not necessarily locked), returns a copy of
 `self` instead.

defs.name: downgrade
defs.docs: Create a [`MutexWeak`] reference to this `Mutex`.

defs.name: get_mut
defs.docs:
Returns a reference to the underlying data, if there are no other
 clones of the `Mutex`.

attributes.value: / Returns a reference to the underlying data, if there are no other

/ place -- the mutable borrow statically guarantees no locks exist.
/ However, if the `Mutex` has already been cloned, then `None` will be

defs.name: lock
defs.docs:
Acquires a `Mutex`, blocking the task in the meantime.  When the
 returned `Future` is ready, this task will have sole access to the
 protected data.

defs.name: ptr_eq
defs.docs: Returns true if the two `Mutex` point to the same data else false.

attributes.value: / Returns true if the two `Mutex` point to the same data else false.

defs.name: with
defs.value:
fn with<B, F, R>(&Self, F) -> /*impl Trait*/ where F: FnOnce(MutexGuard<T>) ->
B + Send + 'static, B: Future<Output = R> + Send + 'static, R: Send + 'static,
T: Send
defs.docs:
Acquires a `Mutex` and performs a computation on its guarded value in a
 separate task.  Returns a `Future` containing the result of the
 computation.

attributes.value: / Acquires a `Mutex` and performs a computation on its guarded value in a
/ separate task.  Returns a `Future` containing the result of the
/ When using Tokio, this method will often hold the `Mutex` for less time
/ than chaining a computation to [`lock`](#method.lock).  The reason is
/ that Tokio polls all tasks promptly upon notification.  However, Tokio
/ does not guarantee that it will poll all futures promptly when their
/ owning task gets notified.  So it's best to hold `Mutex`es within their
/ own tasks, lest their continuations get blocked by slow stacked

defs.name: with_local
defs.value:
fn with_local<B, F, R>(&Self, F) -> /*impl Trait*/ where
F: FnOnce(MutexGuard<T>) -> B + 'static, B: Future<Output = R> + 'static +
Unpin, R: 'static
defs.docs:
Like [`with`](#method.with) but for Futures that aren't `Send`.
 Spawns a new task on a single-threaded Runtime to complete the Future.

attributes.value: / Like [`with`](#method.with) but for Futures that aren't `Send`.
/ Spawns a new task on a single-threaded Runtime to complete the Future.

defs.docs: A `Future` representing a pending `RwLock` exclusive acquisition.

defs.name: RwLock
defs.docs: A Futures-aware RwLock.

attributes.value: / `std::sync::RwLock` cannot be used in an asynchronous environment like
/ Tokio, because an acquisition can block an entire reactor.  This class can
/ be used instead.  It functions much like `std::sync::RwLock`.  Unlike that
/ class, it also has a builtin `Arc`, making it accessible from multiple
/ threads.  It's also safe to `clone`.  Also unlike `std::sync::RwLock`, this
/ class does not detect lock poisoning.

defs.docs: Create a new `RwLock` in the unlocked state.
